questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 67
2 68
3 61
4 61
5 60
6 69
7 65
8 64
9 64
10 66

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

67, 68, 61, 61, 60, 69, 65, 64, 64, 66
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 64? In other words, determine #[𝐱<64]\#[\mathbf{x}<64]. {1:NUMERICAL:=3:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 61? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤61]\#[\mathbf{x}\le61]. {1:NUMERICAL:=3:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 69? In other words, determine #[𝐱>69]\#[\mathbf{x}>69]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0}
  4. How many of the measurements are greater than or equal to 60? In other words, determine #[𝐱≥60]\#[\mathbf{x}\ge60]. {1:NUMERICAL:=10:0}
  5. If 6 of the measurements are less than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=6\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 6. {1:NUMERICAL:=66:0}
  6. If 5 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=5\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 5. {1:NUMERICAL:=64:0}
  7. If 1 of the measurements are greater than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=1\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 1. {1:NUMERICAL:=68:0}
  8. If 9 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=9\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 9. {1:NUMERICAL:=61:0}

generalfeedback.text:
First, it helps to sort the data. 60,61,61,64,64,65,66,67,68,6960, 61, 61, 64, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69

You could use R to sort the data:

sort(c(67,68,61,61,60,69,65,64,64,66))
##  [1] 60 61 61 64 64 65 66 67 68 69

You could also use a spreadsheet. Paste the table into a spreadsheet. Then, highlight the column of measurements and use Sort function.

  1. There are 3 measurements less than 64. Those measurements are 61, 61, 60.
  2. There are 3 measurements less than or equal to 61. Those measurements are 61, 61, 60.
  3. There are 0 measurements greater than 69. Those measurements are .
  4. There are 10 measurements greater than or equal to 60. Those measurements are 67, 68, 61, 61, 60, 69, 65, 64, 64, 66.
  5. Measurement value 66 has 6 measurements less than it, so xc=66x_{\text{c}}=66.
  6. Measurement value 64 has 5 measurements less than or equal to it, so xc=64x_{\text{c}}=64.
  7. Measurement value 68 has 1 measurements greater than it, so xc=68x_{\text{c}}=68.
  8. Measurement value 61 has 9 measurements greater than or equal to it, so xc=61x_{\text{c}}=61.

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 58
2 54
3 59
4 56
5 51
6 52
7 57
8 55
9 58
10 53

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

58, 54, 59, 56, 51, 52, 57, 55, 58, 53
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 57? In other words, determine #[𝐱<57]\#[\mathbf{x}<57]. {1:NUMERICAL:=6:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 54? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤54]\#[\mathbf{x}\le54]. {1:NUMERICAL:=4:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 52? In other words, determine #[𝐱>52]\#[\mathbf{x}>52]. {1:NUMERICAL:=8:0}
  4. How many of the measurements are greater than or equal to 58? In other words, determine #[𝐱≥58]\#[\mathbf{x}\ge58]. {1:NUMERICAL:=3:0}
  5. If 7 of the measurements are less than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=7\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 7. {1:NUMERICAL:=58:0}
  6. If 1 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=1\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 1. {1:NUMERICAL:=51:0}
  7. If 0 of the measurements are greater than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=0\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 0. {1:NUMERICAL:=59:0}
  8. If 5 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=5\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 5. {1:NUMERICAL:=56:0}

generalfeedback.text:

You could use R to sort the data:

sort(c(58,54,59,56,51,52,57,55,58,53))
##  [1] 51 52 53 54 55 56 57 58 58 59

You could also use a spreadsheet. Paste the table into a spreadsheet. Then, highlight the column of measurements and use Sort function.

  1. There are 6 measurements less than 57. Those measurements are 54, 56, 51, 52, 55, 53.
  2. There are 4 measurements less than or equal to 54. Those measurements are 54, 51, 52, 53.
  3. There are 8 measurements greater than 52. Those measurements are 58, 54, 59, 56, 57, 55, 58, 53.
  4. There are 3 measurements greater than or equal to 58. Those measurements are 58, 59, 58.
  5. Measurement value 58 has 7 measurements less than it, so xc=58x_{\text{c}}=58.
  6. Measurement value 51 has 1 measurements less than or equal to it, so xc=51x_{\text{c}}=51.
  7. Measurement value 59 has 0 measurements greater than it, so xc=59x_{\text{c}}=59.
  8. Measurement value 56 has 5 measurements greater than or equal to it, so xc=56x_{\text{c}}=56.

questiontext.text:

In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=3\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 3. {1:NUMERICAL:=28:0}

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 74
2 77
3 70
4 72
5 78
6 73
7 74
8 73
9 78
10 70

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

74, 77, 70, 72, 78, 73, 74, 73, 78, 70
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 77? In other words, determine #[𝐱<77]\#[\mathbf{x}<77]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 74? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤74]\#[\mathbf{x}\le74]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 70? In other words, determine #[𝐱>70]\#[\mathbf{x}>70]. {1:NUMERICAL:=8:0}

In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=3\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 3. {1:NUMERICAL:=73:0}
  6. If 2 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=2\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 2. {1:NUMERICAL:=70:0}

In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=3\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 3. {1:NUMERICAL:=74:0}
  8. If 8 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=8\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 8. {1:NUMERICAL:=72:0}

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 91
2 96
3 99
4 94
5 98
6 99
7 96
8 92
9 97
10 94

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

91, 96, 99, 94, 98, 99, 96, 92, 97, 94
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 96? In other words, determine #[𝐱<96]\#[\mathbf{x}<96]. {1:NUMERICAL:=4:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 96? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤96]\#[\mathbf{x}\le96]. {1:NUMERICAL:=6:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 97? In other words, determine #[𝐱>97]\#[\mathbf{x}>97]. {1:NUMERICAL:=3:0}
  4. How many of the measurements are greater than or equal to 94? In other words, determine #[𝐱≥94]\#[\mathbf{x}\ge94]. {1:NUMERICAL:=8:0}
  5. If 2 of the measurements are less than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=2\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 2. {1:NUMERICAL:=94:0}
  6. If 1 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=1\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 1. {1:NUMERICAL:=91:0}
  7. If 0 of the measurements are greater than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=0\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 0. {1:NUMERICAL:=99:0}
  8. If 2 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=2\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 2. {1:NUMERICAL:=99:0}

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 60
2 60
3 63
4 63
5 67
6 68
7 61
8 62
9 67
10 60

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

60, 60, 63, 63, 67, 68, 61, 62, 67, 60
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 67? In other words, determine #[𝐱<67]\#[\mathbf{x}<67]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 68? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤68]\#[\mathbf{x}\le68]. {1:NUMERICAL:=10:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 60? In other words, determine #[𝐱>60]\#[\mathbf{x}>60]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}
  4. How many of the measurements are greater than or equal to 60? In other words, determine #[𝐱≥60]\#[\mathbf{x}\ge60]. {1:NUMERICAL:=10:0}
  5. If 4 of the measurements are less than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=4\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 4. {1:NUMERICAL:=62:0}
  6. If 4 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=4\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 4. {1:NUMERICAL:=61:0}
  7. If 7 of the measurements are greater than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=7\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 7. {1:NUMERICAL:=60:0}
  8. If 3 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=3\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 3. {1:NUMERICAL:=67:0}

generalfeedback.text:
First, it helps to sort the data. 60,60,60,61,62,63,63,67,67,6860, 60, 60, 61, 62, 63, 63, 67, 67, 68

You could use R to sort the data:

sort(c(60,60,63,63,67,68,61,62,67,60))
##  [1] 60 60 60 61 62 63 63 67 67 68

You could also use a spreadsheet. Paste the table into a spreadsheet. Then, highlight the column of measurements and use Sort function.

  1. There are 7 measurements less than 67. Those measurements are 60, 60, 63, 63, 61, 62, 60.
  2. There are 10 measurements less than or equal to 68. Those measurements are 60, 60, 63, 63, 67, 68, 61, 62, 67, 60.
  3. There are 7 measurements greater than 60. Those measurements are 63, 63, 67, 68, 61, 62, 67.
  4. There are 10 measurements greater than or equal to 60. Those measurements are 60, 60, 63, 63, 67, 68, 61, 62, 67, 60.
  5. Measurement value 62 has 4 measurements less than it, so xc=62x_{\text{c}}=62.
  6. Measurement value 61 has 4 measurements less than or equal to it, so xc=61x_{\text{c}}=61.
  7. Measurement value 60 has 7 measurements greater than it, so xc=60x_{\text{c}}=60.
  8. Measurement value 67 has 3 measurements greater than or equal to it, so xc=67x_{\text{c}}=67.

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 18
2 17
3 18
4 16
5 14
6 17
7 15
8 11
9 15
10 18

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

18, 17, 18, 16, 14, 17, 15, 11, 15, 18
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 18? In other words, determine #[𝐱<18]\#[\mathbf{x}<18]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 17? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤17]\#[\mathbf{x}\le17]. {1:NUMERICAL:=7:0}

In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=8\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 8. {1:NUMERICAL:=14:0}

questiontext.text:
A random procedure generated the following sample (sequence of measurements):

i x
1 52
2 50
3 58
4 55
5 52
6 53
7 59
8 54
9 51
10 59

Here are the measurements shown as a comma separated list:

52, 50, 58, 55, 52, 53, 59, 54, 51, 59
  1. How many of the measurements are less than 59? In other words, determine #[𝐱<59]\#[\mathbf{x}<59]. {1:NUMERICAL:=8:0}
  2. How many of the measurements are less than or equal to 58? In other words, determine #[𝐱≤58]\#[\mathbf{x}\le58]. {1:NUMERICAL:=8:0}
  3. How many of the measurements are greater than 53? In other words, determine #[𝐱>53]\#[\mathbf{x}>53]. {1:NUMERICAL:=5:0}
  4. How many of the measurements are greater than or equal to 50? In other words, determine #[𝐱≥50]\#[\mathbf{x}\ge50]. {1:NUMERICAL:=10:0}
  5. If 5 of the measurements are less than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱<xc]=5\#[\mathbf{x}<x_{\text{c}}] = 5. {1:NUMERICAL:=54:0}
  6. If 7 of the measurements are less than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≤xc]=7\#[\mathbf{x}\le x_{\text{c}}] = 7. {1:NUMERICAL:=55:0}
  7. If 8 of the measurements are greater than xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱>xc]=8\#[\mathbf{x}>x_{\text{c}}] = 8. {1:NUMERICAL:=51:0}
  8. If 2 of the measurements are greater than or equal to xcx_{\text{c}}, and xcx_{\text{c}} is a measurement from sample 𝐱\mathbf{x}, then what is xcx_{\text{c}}? In other words, determine a measurement xcx_{\text{c}} from sequence 𝐱\mathbf{x} such that #[𝐱≥xc]=2\#[\mathbf{x}\ge x_{\text{c}}] = 2. {1:NUMERICAL:=59:0}

  2. There are 8 measurements less than or equal to 58. Those measurements are 52, 50, 58, 55, 52, 53, 54, 51.
  3. There are 5 measurements greater than 53. Those measurements are 58, 55, 59, 54, 59.

  6. Measurement value 55 has 7 measurements less than or equal to it, so xc=55x_{\text{c}}=55.
  7. Measurement value 51 has 8 measurements greater than it, so xc=51x_{\text{c}}=51.
  8. Measurement value 59 has 2 measurements greater than or equal to it, so xc=59x_{\text{c}}=59.
